Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Suite of Demonstration Videos for Introductory Astronomy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing a series of more than 40 videos centered on physical demonstrations that are ideal for use in introductory astronomy courses. The short videos are being made publicly available on the web in a variety of formats and resolutions and easily played or downloaded. The videos are high-quality and contain overlays of graphics and computer simulations to illuminate the underlying concepts. Each video is narrated from a script developed by experts, and thus can be useful in distance education courses as well as in the classroom. Each video is accompanied by interactive instructional materials to engage students in the video.

Intellectual Merit: Concepts from introductory astronomy are identified and ways to illustrate these concepts using demonstration equipment are being developed. Video scripts clearly illustrate the phenomena in a time efficient manner while maintaining the excitement of science. Interactive materials accompany or are incorporated into each video, based on the recommendations of educational research to maximize student learning from demonstrations.

Broader Impacts: The videos and supporting materials are being made available on the web and on DVD images that can easily be downloaded and burned. The videos are hosted on the Astronomy Education web site at the University of Nebraska, a site that is already widely-used by astronomy faculty. Videos are also being hosted on Youtube, Vimeo, and incorporated into the web-based homework system of Norton Publishing. The videos are brief and so are the interactive materials that accompany them. Thus, astronomy faculty can easily incorporate them into an existing instructional structure without disruption. Students respond favorably to the highly-visual nature of the videos, linkages with social media sites, and the brevity of the videos. These videos are being widely adopted and are widely useful in the astronomy classroom and in distance education courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created short videos of demonstrations using physical apparatuses that can be performed in college introductory astronomy classes. The videos are publicly available on the UNL Astronomy channel on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCw5d1S08MW2fqCdiJyfE8yw). They are also available on the Astronomy Education at the University of Nebraska web site (https://astro.unl.edu/video/demonstrationvideos) as embedded YouTube videos and for download as mp4 videos. 

There is substantial literature describing demonstrations that can be performed in the college physics classroom. However, specifying demonstrations for the introductory astronomy classroom is territory that isn?t nearly as well explored. These videos are useful to college faculty by displaying many demonstrations illustrating important astronomy concepts and for a variety of logistical reasons. Instructors at small institutions are unlikely to have access to demonstration equipment and they are also unlikely to have dedicated staff to support setting up demonstrations, nor the time to prepare many demonstrations themselves. The videos are also very useful in distance education and blended classes.

There is a long history of using physics demonstrations in the classroom as both students and faculty enjoy them. However, student learning gains from viewing a demonstration are not appreciable unless it is performed interactively. Educational research has conclusively shown the importance of engaging learners ? making them active participants in the learning process. Thus, this project contains pedagogical elements to facilitate interactive engagement. There are voting questions included in most videos and instructors can stop the video, have students vote, and possibly discuss the question with their peers before voting a second time. Many questions focus on the prediction of the result of a demonstration before showing it, which gets students invested in the outcome. There are also follow-up worksheets available at the Nebraska web site (in pdf and doc formats) for students to complete in collaborative group environments.

Forty-two videos were created. This large number of videos was possible with a modest grant as all production work was completed by talented students ? videographers, artists, demonstrators, and narrators. The videos span a wide range of astronomy topics. Screenshots follow from videos selected to convey this broad topical coverage with explanations of the concepts being illustrated:

Image 1: An armillary sphere is used to illustrate the phases of the moon. The apparatus is configured to demonstrate the phases that are visible shortly after sunrise and the angle between the Sun and Moon as seen by the observer is added in the video.

Image 2:  Convective cells are displayed in a mixture of silicon oil and aluminum powder when placed on a hot plate. Hot material travels upward and cooler material circulates downward. This demonstration models convection near the surface of the sun. 

Image 3: This apparatus simulates an eclipsing binary star system where both stars circle a common center of mass. The motorized platform causes the stars to revolve around the center creating eclipses. It is often used with a light detector to create a graph of the brightness over time on a computer.  

Student interviews and quizzes occurred early in the project to gather information to guide the final format of the videos. More substantial interviews occurred near the conclusion of the project to evaluate student understanding of and engagement with the videos. Student conceptual understanding was generally good and student engagement levels were found to be very good. 

Presentations have been made at several venues to communicate the project to potential adopters and two workshops have been taught for instructors at national meetings. Broad dissemination of the materials to college instructors of astronomy is ongoing.
